plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A bright, cheerful wildflower native to North America with golden-yellow petals surrounding a dark brown central cone. It thrives in meadows and gardens alike, providing nectar for pollinators.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are named for their prominent dark 'eye' at the center of the flower, and they are a symbol of encouragement and justice.

plants.name: Chrysanthemum morifolium
plants.description: A popular cultivated flower known for its wide variety of colors and intricate petal arrangements, often blooming in fall gardens. They are a staple in autumn floral displays.
plants.location: Temperate gardens worldwide, especially East Asia and Europe
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums are the official flower of several countries, including Japan, where they symbolize longevity and rejuvenation.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: A fast-growing Australian tree with bright orange to reddish flowers that attract birds. It blooms prolifically in spring and autumn, bringing vibrant color to woodlands.
plants.bloomingSeason: March to June and September to November
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, Silky Oak is not a true oak but is so named because of its valuable, durable timber.

plants.name: Magnolia grandiflora
plants.description: An evergreen tree native to the southeastern United States, known for its large, fragrant white flowers that bloom intermittently through spring and fall.
plants.bloomingSeason: May to June and sporadically October to November
plants.funFact: The southern magnolia's large, waxy leaves are so tough they repel insects and reduce water loss.
